title: Blunt Hepatic Injury
diagnosis_topic: Grade III liver laceration from blunt abdominal trauma
setup_script: A 22-year-old woman is brought in after a high-speed car crash. She was the restrained driver and denies loss of consciousness. She complains of right upper quadrant abdominal pain but is hemodynamically stable.

dynamic_flow.reply: BP 120/78 mmHg, HR 92 bpm, RR 20/min, Temp 37 C, SpO2 99%.
Mild tenderness in the right upper quadrant without rebound or guarding.
Positive fluid in Morrison's pouch but patient remains stable.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident orders CT scan with IV contrast
dynamic_flow.reply: Grade III laceration of liver with contained subcapsular hematoma; no other injuries.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident initiates observation in ICU with serial exams and hematocrit checks
dynamic_flow.reply: Patient remains stable; no drop in Hgb after 6 hours.
Hgb 12.5 g/dL, platelets 210 K/uL, liver enzymes mildly elevated.
Not needed unless active arterial blush or hemodynamic instability develops.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident prematurely sends patient home
dynamic_flow.reply: Patient returns in shock from delayed hemorrhage.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident asks about non-operative management criteria
dynamic_flow.reply: Hemodynamic stability, lack of peritonitis, transfusion < 2 units.
Bed rest initially, then limited activity for 6 weeks with follow-up imaging.
Watch for biliary leak, hemobilia or abscess formation.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident counsels regarding seat belt use and traffic safety

critical_decision_points: Assessment of blunt abdominal trauma with focus on hepatic injury
Appropriate use of FAST and CT imaging
Criteria for non-operative management of liver injuries
Monitoring and recognizing delayed hemorrhage or complications
Counseling on activity restrictions and follow-up
